item.title: bhaktapur
item.description: Bhaktapur is a small city located on outskirts of the KTM valley. Known for its well preserved Malla dynasty architecture and immaculate temples. It is a heavily trafficked location with a steady flow of both locals and tourists. Determining which group I fall under is an existential dread for another day. A lot of travel guides online describe Bhaktapur as a city “frozen in time” but I’m not a big fan of this descriptor because I feel like it discounts everyday people that are carrying on their normal lives within the city.

item.title: riding a bike
item.description: Moving around KTM, you’ll notice an immense density of motorbikes. Most are trudging along at a snail’s pace beside the slow moving traffic. Others are weaving in and out through any openings on the road. Lanes are an artificial construct and often times, you’ll see oncoming traffic on the right side (Nepal is a lefty country) due to overflow. My cousin described driving in Nepal as a real life video game as your sole focus becomes to navigate through the tiniest of streets and avoid any dynamic obstacles on the road.

item.title: the weary road
item.description: Every time I visit Nepal, I make my customary trek from Butwal to Tansen. The entire journey is just 43.1 km or 26 miles for folks at home. However, the trip takes well over two hours because the road meanders beside sheer cliffs the whole time and is heavily trafficked leading to minor congestions and extreme wear. For reference, traveling 48 km (30 miles) back in VA took me roughly 45 minutes.

item.title: phone number store
item.description: Getting a new phone number is fairly easy in Nepal. You can go to any authorized seller and pick up a sim card after filling out a single page form. After an hour, your new phone number will be registered with Nepal Telecom and you can make and receive calls as you please. A pretty standard process however my experience inside this one phone number store in Dillibazar was anything but.

item.title: journeys
item.description: When I told my cousin about a half baked idea to go live in Nepal for a few months on our amtrak up to NYC, I wasn’t thinking that six months later I would be on stuck in Doha for eight hours well on my way to KTM. The first 12 hours of the trip from IAD was unexpectedly pleasant. The real fun started as soon as I landed in Doha.
